dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIRDS ARE FLUSHED FROM HIDING. A soldier carrying an auto weapon rises up out of the grass and looks around. A mort shell explodes nearby. There are no sound effects. He see unperturbed. Several more explosions in the field. The soldier motions with his arm and: FIFTY MORE SOLDIERS RISE UP OUT OF THE GRASS More small  explosions.

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE FRAME
dialogues.text: With a click-click of a camera -- still no fx.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOLDIERS RUN THROUGH THE GRASS FOLLOWING THEIR LEADER
dialogues.text: they do, the platoon leader waves his arms again. FIVE ELEPHANTS CHARGE OUT OF THE SHRUBBERY Through a fiel of small mortar explosions.

dialogues.speaker: FREEZE FRAME
dialogues.text: With the click-click of a camera. THE ELEPHANTS CHARGE OUT ACROSS THE PLAINS Each carries a enormous load of supplies, and each is ridden by a soldie with a rifle. A HELICOPTER GUNSHIP DIVES OUT OF THE SKY firing rockets the soldiers and elephants. A tribal mask is painted on t nose of the chopper.

dialogues.speaker: THE ELEPHANTS REAR UP IN TERROR
dialogues.text: The soldiers on the elephants stand up and aim rifles at chopper and begin firing. THE CHOPPER ATTACKS THE ELEPHANTS against an African suns

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door slams o.s. and the figure of RUSSELL PRICE, 30, ap at the top of some stairs. Sleepy-eyed, he pulls on a mul pocketed fishing vest over a baggy shirt. He carries a be up canvas bag over his shoulder. A BLACK WOMAN, 40, sleeps at the lobby switchboard desk.  Another OLD BLACK MAN sweeps the floor. Price mumbles a ' morning' and goes to two vintage WW II vending machines - one for candy, one for Coca-Cola. He buys two candy bars a coke, and begins eating his "breakfast" as he crosses t lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIMMY, a cab driver, has been sleeping in a chair against the wall. Several street vendors have their wares laid ou on the sidewalk against the hotel. Some are shaded by  makeshift awnings, some are not. Jimmy rises as Price arr there is familiar ritual in their greeting. They cross the street together toward Jimmy's waiting tax a hand-painted purple old American car with the words on door, "New People's Taxi Company" and Jimmy's name in scr above it. Price hands a candy bar to Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Jimmy, think you could  squeeze me in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is you would care to go at  once, Mr. Price?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bang-bang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty dollar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price hands him a wad of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a thief, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy smiles broadly, nodding, then points to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booteeful picture, huh, snap-snap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do skies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men get into the strange cab parked in front of a open marketplace just starting to come alive; the cab dri off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The taxi arrives, and Price gets out. Price ambles over to stand in the early morning shade aga an old building. A hand-painted image of Che Guevarra --  with an X painted over it -- is on one wall. Price pulls joint from his pocket and lights up, taking a hit. The sounds of war machinery soon interrupt the stillness. Price hurries to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price pulls a handful of colored rags from his pocket and picks out a yellow kerchief, tying it to his arm. Price t steps boldly into the street in front of the approaching  convoy. He exchanges shouts with an officer in a jeep, an with a motion is given permission to join.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE CLIMBS INTO THE LAST OF THREE TROOP TRUCKS
dialogues.text: Each truck is filled with perhaps 25 African soldiers in  khaki, each holding an automatic rifle. Another jeep foll towing a World War II cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerily) Hi, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers look over disinterestedly. Two dozen cases o Coca-Cola are tied to a stretcher among stacks of guns. As Price settles in for the ride, he begins pulling camer from his bag. Quickly and automatically, rarely looking, switches lenses, loads film, and prepares his cameras. He has done this a thousand times. A SINGLE WHITE SOLDIER -- OATES, rises from among the bla and shakily makes his way toward Price. A mercenary dress in a ragged uniform of his own design, carries two machin guns and a .45. He smiles broadly, recognizing Price. HOD slaps Price's hands as if they were teammates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'damn, Price, you tuna sucking piece  of raw meat -- whatchyou goin' to  Zambeze for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought I'd get some great shots of  your head gettin' blown to  smithereens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smithereens?! Be a great fuckin'  picture, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be a prize winner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Ya think so? (beat; changing tone) Trade ya some greenies for a joint. (beat) I gotta have a joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the wagon, man, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Ahh. Dope-wise, this place sucks. (looks around, leans  in confidentially) Lotta fuckin' coons around here, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They nod. He laughs obscenely and deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were fighting for the  Government?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. This is the Government.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the Rebels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck they are. This is a Government  convoy to Calunda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Abou-Deian Revolutionary  Front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shitting me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Finally Oates starts laughing uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These guys be pissed if they knew,  eh? (Price nods in  agreement; Oates  suddenly gets serious) This is the dumbest motherfucker I  ever signed up for. Don't pay shit  either. (Price nods in  agreement) Nicaragua. That's the spot. Cheap  shrimp, lotta rays -- real thin in  the spook department too, dig?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convoy rumbles past a check-point into a small airfie containing a motley collection of DC-3's and old planes. RUSSIAN ADVISORS and THREE CUBAN ADVISORS watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hell... I wonder where the  fuckin' Guvmint is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, the cab of the truck is rocked with a morta shell and explodes. Soldiers scramble to safety. Some gra the guns being transported. TWO SOLDIERS GRAB THE STRETCHER OF COKE and start running for safety. Smoke and explosions are everywhere -- they  abandon their cargo and run for cover. OATES SCRAMBLES TO SAFE GROUND quickly and instinctively, looking around wildly to "read" the situation. Price dive next to him. A SOLDIER IS HIT AND GOES DOWN NEARBY, staggering towards Price and Oates.

dialogues.speaker: A DC-3 GOES UP IN FLAMES IN THE BACKGROUND
dialogues.text: THE WOUNDED SOLDIER REACHES FOR OATES who darts out quick and drags the injured Rebel to safety. PRICE HAS HIS CAMERAS OUT AT ONCE and is firing away. TWO REBEL SOLDIERS POINT TO THE STRETCHER OF COCA-COLA an start moving toward it through the smoke. They want to re the soft drinks. PRICE LEAPS FROM HIS BUNKER AND RACES TOWARD THEM dangero waving and shouting as he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold it! Hold it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't speak English but stop at his craziness. PRICE STOPS AND AIMS HIS CAMERA, and as he does he motion for the soldiers to continue. P.O.V. THE FRAMED IMAGE -- SOLDIERS, SMOKE AND COKE IN B. As the soldiers move toward the Coke, Price snaps picture after picture.

dialogues.speaker: A MORTAR EXPLOSION BLOWS THE COCA-COLA TO A MILLION BITS
dialogues.text: two soldiers stop short -- several more steps and they wo have been killed. Price's intrusion has accidentally save them. The two soldiers run toward safety, bewildered and  scared.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE AIRFIELD
dialogues.text: Gradually the airfield comes back to life. Several teams medics run with stretchers from the hut and begin gatheri bodies. Rebel soldiers appear from every conceivable shel and move across the field. Oates emerges and meets Price on the torn up runway amids the rubble. They look around at the devastation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess we know where the  Guvmint is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cynically) You can walk to work from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Convenient, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates starts to walk away, then stops and speaks earnestl as if trying to connect to a real world that doesn't exis

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother just got married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know your brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the distant roar of a jet. All the soldiers on field scan the horizon; Price looks up. The air raid sire goes off.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIERS DIVE TO COVER
dialogues.text: JET STREAKS OVERHEAD and, instead of rockets and bombs, i drops something else: THE SKY IS FILLED WITH A MILLION PIECES OF PAPER The jet  pulls out and disappears. All is quiet again as the milli papers flutter in the sky above the airfield. Out of frustration a single soldier fires a couple of sho at the paper. Price grabs a piece of paper out of the air. It is:

dialogues.speaker: A PICTURE OF A SWIMMING POOL IN FRONT OF A CALIFORNIA HOU
dialogues.text: HE STARES AT THE IMAGE and turns it over. There is writin on the backside in Spanish and Russian. He looks around. OATES WANDERS OVER with a handful of the leaflets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great shit, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price tries to read the writing on the back as Oates look at a leaflet familiarly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: U.S. Gummint offers this house to  any Cuban pilot flying Migs for the  Rebels who chooses to defect to  America with a Russian jet. We know  they ain't gonna run off with no  planes -- but the Rebs don't --  They're scared. They start thinking  about that swimming pool. Damn near  smell that chlorine. Starts workin'  on 'em, and pretty soon they don't  let the Cubies near a Mig. Use their  own spook pilots and destroy their  own air force in a week. Guaran-fuckin- teed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C.I.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly) Smartest guys in the world. (afterthought) Hey, you gotta scoop here, eh? You'll  be famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OATES shakes hands with Price who looks at the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dispassionately) Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around) I gotta run... have a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates heads off across the runway as papers continue blow down out of the sky; Price looks up and speaks to himself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAIRE STRYDER, 40, reads a report over the telephone as times the call with a stopwatch. A photograph of Claire's high-school-aged daughter sits on her dresser. ALEX GRAZIER, 50, struggles with his tie and a drink at a dresser in the adjoining room. Their connected rooms are  littered with hand washed laundry and the paraphernalia o their trade -- typewriters, tape decks, books, notes,  pictures. Their love affairs of three years is ending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on the phone) "...and so this strange war that  features two provincial governments,  three rival liberation fronts, and  at least twenty-five tribal  associations, grinds into its seventh  year..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex picks up a Melodica, a novelty wind instrument, and  tries to court her with "Caravan" as she files her story. Though mildly put off, she maintains her cool throughout call. He thinks he's Paul Desmond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...The Battle for the Airfield at  Abou Deia is just another chapter in  this endless story. From Ndjamena,  Chad, this is Claire Stryder." (beat) No -- you didn't hear any music --  must be the connection. Okay? So  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up and rises more irritated than angered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, don't play that God damn thing  when I'm filing. (beat) We're late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly expressed, her anger passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my party -- we'll be late. You  called it a "strange war" and an  "endless story." If you filed that  story for me, I'd say you were  editorialishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to editorialize. You drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex loves to be melo-dramatic and is quite conscious of ability to charm. He's also aware that it's worn off with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drunk? Only with the memories of  making love with you on the plains  of Fianga as the first Army of  Liberation marched in and opened  fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And freed the Proletariat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex raises a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the party without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves -- he quickly puts on his coat and follows her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I don't want to go to this  stupid party. I'm bad at false  modesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're great at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She straightens his half-tied tie in an act of familiar  affection rather than motherliness. Nervousness. She spea calmly -- this is ground they have already covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, you're going to make a great  anchorman in New York and undoubtedly  I could be a Pulitzer Prize winning  hostess -- but I'm not going with  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can work out of the East Coast.  We'll get a place on Long Island and  burn our suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still like suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every Saturday night we'll have a  party... invite all our friends, sit  out on the veranda and interview  each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done all that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't. (beat; changes tack) Well, God dammit, I'm getting tired  of memorizing who's the president of  the... Republic of Maldives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mamoon Abdul Gayoom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he succeeded Mamoon Abdul  Gayeem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both smile slightly as the elevator comes to a stop. The door doesn't open, and the light flickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm tired of Third World  elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He bangs the door with his fist. It opens, and they enter dismal hallway. The sounds of a party come from beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach the door to the party, he speaks with ne toughness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Abou Deia and New York. I'm  going to Nicaragua with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard it's a neat little war  with a nice hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cheer goes up for Alex as he and Claire enter. Party ha booze, hand-made signs reading "Bon Voyage," etc. Fifteen journalists of varying nationalities cover this backwater war. Though both upset, they act as if everything is normal. PRICE STANDS ON A CHAIR AT THE CENTER summoning Alex who  moves through the group with ease, instantly at home. Pri holds up a bottle of champagne in toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, get up here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex climbs on a chair next to Price who puts his arm aro him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the man who gave me my first job,  and fired me from my first job...  and gave me my second job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And fired you from your second job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a few words, Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible! Can't be done! etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However miserable, Alex shines in these situations. He ra his hand -- silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be asking yourself what  exactly are you doing here in this  "strange war, just another chapter  in an endless story... that grinds  into its seventh year..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire slips to the side bar and pours herself a drink,  watching Alex and shaking her head with some affection. JIMMY, THE CAB DRIVER, ENTERS WITH A CAKE covered with  candles. The crowd parts for the cake shaped like the cou of Chad. The crowd begins singing "Caravan" in a half-dru tribute to a man they like and respect. PRICE MOVES AROUND THE ROOM TAKING PICTURES of the party; is all casual, silly, fun. THROUGH CAMERA P.O.V.'S OF ALEX IN A PARTY HAT, whip pan CABBY WITH THE CAKE, whip pan to DRUNKEN JOURNALISTS. THROUGH CAMERA P.O.V. OF CLAIRE -- FREEZE FRAME, pan foll her as she moves through the room -- FREEZE FRAME, she pi up another drink and leaves through a side door -- FREEZE FRAME. ALEX GIVES IN AND JOINS THE SINGING, enjoying his own tri once he has managed to give in to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire's face is also covered with tears as she smokes,  wandering idly among clothespinned photos. A part of her  life is ending -- life with Alex -- but it's not ending  neatly. A ROW OF HANGING PHOTOGRAPHS catches her eye. She stops a looks closely -- then laughs in spite of herself at a ser of pictures: PHOTO OF A TALL AFRICAN NATIVE WITH A COCK S

dialogues.speaker: DAYS.
dialogues.text: CLAIRE PULLS THE PHOTO OF ALEX AND HER from the clip and  looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I didn't know you were here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you did. You were taking pictures  of me all over the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yeah... you looked great.  Why aren't you partying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He notices the picture she's looking at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I printed that up for Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be the greatest thing  you could give him right now... (beat) We just split up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I'm sorry. Who left who this  time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the villain... I thought it could  be a little cleaner this time -- me  in Central America, him in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's pretty clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he's decided to go to Nicaragua  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To cover you or the war?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To cover everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Price moves behind her and gently kisses her on ear. She smiles quickly and nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He kisses her on the neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For godsakes, Russell, listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sounds of the party can be heard. He ignores them and moves around her, trying to kiss her on the lips. She put her hand over his mouth. Price reacts strongly, flaring slightly and withdrawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to wait for you again.  We've been circling each other since  the Montreal Olympics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a genius of bad timing. (beat) I'm going back to the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She heads to the door; Price stays. She stops before gett there, hesitates, then pulls the PHOTO OF THE ELEPHANT fr the string and returns to Price, handing him the photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a great shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've heard the light in Nicaragua's  even better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't respond. They stand for several moments -- the sounds of the party get louder. She turns and heads to Al celebration, leaving Price alone in the darkroom. PRICE LOOKS AT CLAIRE AS SHE LEAVES, stares aimlessly for several moments, then focuses back on his PHOTO OF THE  ELEPHANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gradually PULL BACK to reveal other magazines, candy, cig Nicaraguan toys, all in a corner shop, and finally: A FIRE TRUCK LEADS A PROCESSION through the streets -- a  group of middle class Nicaraguan women carry a banner tha reads "Our Revolution is in Christ" (in Spanish), followe by three Catholic PRIESTS in bright robes, followed by a  sound truck with P.A. system, followed by hundreds of  townspeople carrying banana leaves and religious signs. A are singing a Catholic hymn in a swaying, hypnotic rhythm Small red and black flags are scattered throughout. A CAB DRIVING THROUGH THE STREETS runs into the parade an stops. Price sits in the front seat -- his luggage is tie precariously to the roof. The trunk of the cab has been  smashed in beyond repair. Price hops out of the cab with camera bag -- he doesn't know what the parade is about bu it looks great. He hands the cabbie some money to stay ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He runs to join the procession. PRICE HOPS ONTO THE RUNNING BOARD OF THE FIRE TRUCK and a simultaneously his light meter is out. HE is surrounded b images: SMALL GIRLS DRESSED AS ANGELS LINE THE STREET,

dialogues.speaker: GROUPS ALONG THE PARADE ROUTE.
dialogues.text: PRICE IS QUICKLY TAKING PICTURES OF EVERYTHING, changing  cameras, occasionally taking a quick light reading; his  actions are instinctive and automatic. Suddenly: TEN YOUNG TEENAGERS BURST INTO THE PARADE They wear red a black handkerchiefs, baseball caps, and strange masks. Th are chanting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael, Rafael, Rafael... libre o  muerte... Rafael...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LARGE PAINTING OF THE FACE OF RAFAEL is carried aloft o stick, draped with red and black scarves. PRICE PHOTOGRAPHS the boys and the painting. NATIONAL GUARD SOLDIERS SHOVE INTO THE PARADE Up and down the street they spring into action, running for position  with their guns. An ice cream vendor is knocked down, a mother clutches he "angel" daughter, another child is whisked inside a door the Soldiers break into the procession. THE "MUCHACHOS" WITH RAFAEL TURN TO RUN but realize that soldiers have cut off their escape. THREE SOLDIERS BREAK into the parade and are separated fr the boys only by a group of Priests. Trapped, the boys pa but as the SOLDIERS push towards them: THE PRIESTS BLOCK THE SOLDIERS and intentionally scuffle  with them, allowing the boys just enough time to dart int house. One of the boys drops the picture of Rafael as he  heads in the door. THE CROWD PUSHES FORWARD, the route to the door is blocke off, and the boys escape. SOLDIERS FIND THE PORTRAIT OF RAFAEL and shoot it full of holes with their automatic weapons. PRICE PHOTOGRAPHS "RAFAEL" as his image is ripped to shre with bullets. The singing and the parade march on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlooking Managua is a sub-tropical paradise that seems far removed from a brutal civil war, this one time touris watering hole serves as home base to the international pr The cab pulls up, and Price gets out. The driver unties h luggage from the roof as TWO PRESS CORPS MEMBERS recogniz Price and greet him as an old friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX SITS WITH A BEAUTIFUL NICARAGUAN WOMAN, 35, at a tab as PRESS CORPS MEMBERS mingle. A man we will come to know HUB KITTLE, 40, dressed New York casual, table hops in th b.g. PRICE SEES ALEX and sneaks over to drop the Time magazine over his shoulder onto the table in front of him. Without looking up, Alex knows Price has arrived. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to Managua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands warmly, and Price sits down. Price point to the cover as a beer is served.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have something to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I thought of calling your  photographs "Pictures from a Lost  War"... I'm great at captions -- the  New York editors loved it since none  of them knew where the hell Chad was  anyway -- it legitimized their  ignorance, got you a cover, me a  feature, and packaged a class struggle  in two words. Nifty, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell acknowledges ISELA CRUZ sitting with Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Russell Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... this is Isela Cruz. She  works for the hotel and helps out as  a translator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BACKGROUND CLAIRE WALKS INTO THE POOL-BAR AREA She carries her handbag and some papers -- she stops short se Price sitting with Alex. She hesitates, starts toward the stops, and sits down at the bar at the opposite end of th pool. Price sees her, and she sees Price. They pretend they don Price turns to Isela and launches into a stream of broken chauvinistic Spanish with his usual elegance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Looks like you guys have a lot of  bang-bang down here, eh? Little  misunderstanding between the poets  and the government?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Misunderstanding?!" "Down here"  it's called a war. It started in  nineteen thirty. Before you were  born.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Spanish is a little out of shape --  what'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he considers it an honor to  be able to photograph our war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price looks at each of them and decides not to push.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell's got a way with words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a helluva translator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm much in demand around  here. Will you excuse me? If you  have any questions, just ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex stands to help Isela from her chair. Price presses o instinctively and effortlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Rafael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends who you ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex turns to Isela, who stops as she rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael? Comandante Rafael. He is  either a Marxist dupe of Russia and  Cuba... (beat) ...or the most popular leader of a  most popular democratic revolution. (to Price cynically) Take your pick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't really give a damn... but  the guy's got a great face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat, then Price asks his question almost sexually, as he thinks he could seduce Isela, Rafael, the whole war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would he like to be photographed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd never find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanta lay odds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would lose. (beat) You must excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to leave again, and again he stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just one more thing -- is Rafael  owned by the C.I.A. or the K.G.B.?  I'll figure out the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isela seems to welcome the question. Her tone is less fli and she focuses hard on Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Price... the world is not divided  into East and West anymore. It is  divided into North and South. By the  time you people figure that out --  it will be too late. (beat) Congratulations on your cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches his Time magazine, kisses Alex on the cheek, floats magically through the pool area. Price frames her with his fingers as if composing a shot. P.O.V. OF ISELA THROUGH PRICE'S FINGERS Isela kisses anot journalist, grabs someone's hand, and lands gracefully at another table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far this war's got it all over  Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna have a ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX PLACES HIS HAND OVER PRICE'S "FRAME" blocking out hi view of the sexy Isela. Though Alex's tone is gentle, the threat is obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands off. I need an interpreter  more than you do right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price takes the hint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still hanging in there with  Claire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex chooses his words carefully and speaks slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hanging in there like an interim  post-war government waiting for the  palace to be overrun... by younger  men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence and an uneasiness that Alex intended. Price manag a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Younger men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex smiles disarmingly. CLAIRE RISES AT THE OPPOSITE BAR, picks up her papers, an heads straight for the two men with a bounce in her step. BOTH MEN ARE A BIT SURPRISED AT HER ENTRANCE and she hand stack of mail to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Alex... Russell! When did you  get in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shakes Price's hand in a friendly manner that comes o awkwardly, then races past the moment to address and ente both men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going to believe this --  I just beat you guys and everybody  else here to a story... (she teases them) ...exclusive... eat your heart out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd ya get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been promised a private  interview with Tacho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Congratulations. The bastard won't  talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Tacho?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to Price as if everyone knows who Tacho is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's President Somoza's nickname.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know who the players are  yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to order you a hot dog and a  program?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit of tension and awkwardness -- Claire quickly takes  control and changes the tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellas! No fighting after six at  night, all right? Curfew. (beat) C'mon, we've all got something to  celebrate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Corrugated metal roofs, thatched hut booths, a strange  combination of decorative and architectural devices. DAIS WILLIAMS, a large black woman from Nicaragua, sings "I Le My Heart in San Francisco" with a mediocre jazz group. HUB KITTLE is present, and other journalists drop by the  table to say hello. A BOY PHOTOGRAPHER, 13, aims an ancient bellows type pola at a booth in which Claire sits between Alex and Price. T are holding a pose indefinitely while the boy struggles w the camera. They hold up the TIME COVER and a couple of b in celebration, and when he finally snaps the picture -- flash. The boy puts the camera down disappointedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in broken English) Sometimes it doesn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three journalists relax their pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE BANDSTAND Daisy has just finished "San Francisco" spots Alex, motioning to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladeez and Gen'mun, hep me get Aaleex  ov' here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy applauds lightly for Alex to join them. Alex is equ pleased and embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's not many piano bars left  where I'm still welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she can't sing in the key of C  I'm in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex excuses himself and joins Daisy on the bandstand. Pr and Claire are left alone in the booth as Price hands the repaired camera back to the boy. ALEX AT THE PIANO begins a slow, easy cocktail version of "Stardust," the song of his generation perhaps, and he se happy, seduced by his own chords. PRICE AND CLAIRE RESUME THEIR POSE, and this time the cam FLASHES. Price pays for the picture from the boy. At first there is a moment of awkwardness between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Well"... you finished your assignment  in Chad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got Africa all wrapped up and pouched  to my editor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She smiles and relaxes a bit at the typical Price remark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to love this war,  Russell... there's good guys, bad  guys, cheap shrimp... (an afterthought) And Alex is still singing in the  background. (beat) I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get alone somewhere to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX BEGINS SINGING as he plays. He sings like a trumpet  player -- no voice but great phrasing. He half smiles as sings, enjoying the song and enjoying making them  uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder why I spend these  lonely nights, Dreaming of a song...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... he's doing it on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is one of the world's leading  experts on military strategy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't really want to talk about Alex though his pres is unavoidable. Price changes gears, gets slightly goofy, and steers the conversation to more comfortable turf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, I just got off the boat...  gimme the scoop on Nicaragua...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... about sixty years ago the  U.S. Marines invaded to protect  American business interests and put  down a peasant revolt led by a little  man who wore a giant cowboy hat -- his name was Augusto Sandino... In  nineteen thirty-four he was murdered  at a peace conference, and the Somoza  family has ruled ever since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no... I don't mean the stuff  about the peasants -- I mean the  real stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows what he means, but she wants to tease him a bit first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "real" stuff?... you mean a  history of class struggle in agrarian  societies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, c'mon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay... well... (beat) Just a couple things. (beat) One -- there's only two kinds of  beer available -- Tona and Victoria.  Victoria's better. (beat) And two -- if you see Miss Panama  hanging around the hotel bar -- hot,  hot, hot -- but don't touch. She  belongs to Tacho, and if anybody  gets caught with her then El  Presidente has promised to personally  cut off the guy's... (unsure which word to  use)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pecker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... and throw it into Lake  Managua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the lake's already polluted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is impressed, and yet another new face drops by the booth -- they both recognize and see him coming, a  contemporary of Price, REGIS FLYNN, a scraggly British  journalist who heads over to their table holding three be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters to Claire) Is there anybody here we don't know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regis slides into their booth, happy to see them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'damn, Price... kudos on the African  snaps. (shakes hands, a  perfunctory kiss on  her cheek) Jeez, Claire, I haven't seen you  since...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Mile Island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... shit... (wistfully) Holiday Inn, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods; they all sip beers and watch Alex sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A teenage DISHWASHER looks around nervously, then pulls a paper sack from off the shelf, removing a strange mask fr it. He pulls the mask over his head. Then from the bag he removes a hand-made zip gun, puts a bullet in it, and dar into the shadows of a nook, waiting. BACK TO THE BOOTH where Regis softly croons a few bars of "Stardust" into Claire's mike. The three of them are havi a good time, mildly drunk at best, and uninhibited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we hear Alex's gentle rendition of the standard, a NEC COUPLE moves back into the shadows of the club. Each pull on a mask, as in the b.g.:

dialogues.speaker: ISELA AND AN ELEGANT MAN ARRIVE AT THE CLUB
dialogues.text: The man, somehow out of place, dresses with casual contin style, not overdone but expensive and tasteful -- clearly from another world. He wears a neat hat and moves gracefu Isela looks stunning, dressed for the evening. The DOORMA greets them familiarly. Isela casually checks her watch as they enter the club. The masked couple in the shadows check their watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Isela and the man enter, commanding attention without  trying. Isela stops at the piano long enough to kiss Alex gently before sitting in the booth with the man. IN PRICE'S BOOTH the new arrivals have caught their atten Price and Alex still clown slightly, and Claire teases th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... Louis Jordan walks in, and  I'm sitting with the Everly Brothers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you fall in love -- that's  Marcel Jazy... friend of wine, women,  and Somoza. They say he's a  businessman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) He's a businessman in search of a  business... he doesn't try very hard  to cover up his connections to the  C.I.A...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But look at his moves -- can the  C.I.A. light cigarettes like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with the Everly Brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE WAITER ARRIVES AT PRICE'S BOOTH and sets down three s cocktails and more champagne, as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens quickly, and three more MEN IN MASKS enter quick BACK TO THE BOOTH as the waiter speaks with a firm coolne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please stay at your table, and you  won't be hurt.

dialogues.speaker: A FACE IN A MASK MOVES QUICKLY PAST PRICE'S TABLE
dialogues.text: ANOTHER MASKED FACE COMES OUT OF THE KITCHEN The dishwash waves a gun.

dialogues.speaker: TWO MASKED FACES
dialogues.text: DOOR The woman carries an automatic rifle and guards the  entrance. THREE MASKED FACES APPEAR Almost materialize from thin ai moving silently and without commotion. The music winds do slowly. (Six Guerrillas total) A GUERRILLA QUICKLY SPRAYS AN IMAGE ON THE WALL With a fe deftly drawn strokes, the FACE OF RAFAEL magically appear The name "RAFAEL" is written under the face, then other n and revolutionary slogans. As this takes place:

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN GUERRILLA HAS A GUN AT THE HEAD OF A NICARAGUAN
dialogues.text: BUSINESSMAN The middle-aged, well-dressed local sits with his wife and two other men. They freeze in fear, the nigh freezes, as the GUERRILLAS take control of the room swift and smoothly. ONE GUERRILLA FACES THE NICARAGUAN BUSINESSMAN at the tab and speaks loudly but without panic. The masked Guerrilla around the room are serious but nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) We do not want to waste any ammunition  on a head as empty as yours -- but  we will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) What is this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Shut up! Get up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BUSINESSMAN refuses. The GUERRILLA LEADER takes a han grenade from his pocket and pulls the pin without hesitat then holds the grenade in front of him fearlessly, inches away from the Businessman's face. The Businessman rises slowly. The LEADER motions toward t back door of the club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You are coming with us -- you will  not be hurt -- we will trade you for  the release of some Nicaraguans who  care about Nicaragua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman with the gun shoves it into the man's head forc him to move toward the kitchen door. PRICE TAKES PICTURES QUICKLY WITH A TINY CAMERA that fits into the palm of his hand. Neatly, surreptitiously, and c Price is coolest in any crisis. CLAIRE PUNCHES ON HER TINY TAPE RECORDER instinctively, a a tiny red light comes on. THE BUSINESSMAN IS SHOVED TO THE DOOR He hesitates, afrai to leave the room. The Guerrilla shoves the grenade in hi face; the woman sticks the gun into his neck even deeper.

dialogues.speaker: THE BANDMEMBERS
dialogues.text: BANDSTAND Alex trips over the drum set slightly -- a clan clash of cymbals startles everyone, and as the drama free

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN DOOR SWINGS OPEN, AND THE BOY PHOTOGRAPHER EM
dialogues.text: Innocently, the young boy struts out of the kitchen to se what's going on, and as he does the DOOR STRIKES THE ARM THE GUERRILLA WITH THE GRENADE, and: THE GRENADE IS KNOCKED FREE For an instant, everything  freezes, and: THE GRENADE ROLLS ACROSS THE FLOOR Daisy Williams, the si runs away screaming as the grenade comes to rest near a  crowded section of the club. A Guerrilla guarding the side door rushes for it, picks i up, and as he does: THE GRENADE EXPLODES IN THE GUERRILLA'S HAND A brutal  explosion -- the ceiling caves in partially, the musical  instruments explode, and: THE SANDINISTA GUERRILLAS DART FROM THE ROOM through vari doors. The boy photographer lies bloodied. The Guerrilla picked up the grenade is a barely recognizable corpse. Th Businessman is soiled but unhurt. ONE HALF OF THE CLUB BREAKS OUT IN FLAME As a broken gas  pipe feeds a sudden outburst of fire, the club's patrons  panic -- screaming and shoving towards the door as the RO LIGHTS UP, and: PRICE'S LIGHT METER IS OUT AT ONCE followed quickly by a  35mm camera, quickly clicking off picture after picture o the club amid the flames and panic. The new light makes h job easier. PRICE TAKES A LIGHT READING near the body of the boy  photographer. He sees the boy's camera lying nearby. Pric puts away his light meter and feels the boy's pulse, then puts his ear to the boy's heart -- making sure he is not  still alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chaos of a busy, cramped Telex room. A switchboard -- several journalists trying to place phone calls. Press co and go -- coffee, cigarettes, and half-eaten sandwiches. CLAIRE TEARS A STORY OFF THE TELEX while Price stands to side of the action eating a sandwich and watching. ALEX STANDS AT THE CENTER OF IT ALL Established as the se figure (or one of them) to whom other, younger journalist come for information. A YOUNG JOURNALIST, a Time stringer, is slightly distraug on the phone, and interrupts Alex's dealing with others,  cupping the phone, to announce:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...it's Charlie, from New York --  says that a terrorist bombing of a  Central American restaurant isn't  big enough to hold for the world  section...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him we have pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him there were pieces of body  in the piano, and somebody was  singing, "I Left My Heart in San  Francisco." (beat) What's he got better than that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the Pope visiting Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex grabs the phone in disgust and launches in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the Pope, Charlie. Every week  you got the Pope somewhere. This is  a very big story down here because  it's the first sign of fighting in  Managua. (beat) Yeah, well get a map and look up  Nicaragua -- ya drive to New Orleans  and turn left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Charlie argues on the other end of the phone, Alex  initials papers and performs several jobs at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like hell I'm editorializing, the  whole thing happened in a roomful of  C.I.A. and press. What do you want?! (beats) How do I know they were C.I.A.? They  wore name tags, what do you think?  We're backing a Fascist again -- I  know that ain't news, but see if you  can find an angle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUB KITTLE has been floating through the room and, upon  hearing the word "fascist," takes offense and approaches  Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! There's fascists and then there's  fascists, right? Be careful how you  throw words like that around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex ignores Hub though he is slightly pestered by him, a continues on the phone as he initials papers brought to h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have any pictures of Rafael  because nobody knows where the son  of a bitch is, and anybody crazy  enough to go after him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex spots Price who is standing nearby, still eating a  sandwich, still enjoying the high energy buzz of the room Alex directs his next line so that Price cannot fail to g the message. Alex plays the moment coolly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...is liable to get his nuts shot  off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub nods seriously, in agreement. Price turns. Alex smile Price smiles. Alex hangs up, grumbling, then turns his  attention to the persistent Hub Kittle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well g'bye... (to Hub) Who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending a hand) Hub Kittle. I'm with Lewitsky and  Knupp -- New York. We have a client  down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is irritated but fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: President Somoza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is incredulous that Somoza employs a New York P.R. f Hub is professionally used to this reaction -- no panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know... (beat) But there's an untold story here. I  mean, the man has a point of view  too, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex turns to leave; Hub corners him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a national anthem contest  going on right now, and you guys are  ignoring it. Lotta human interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex turns to other business though Hub persists. ELSEWHERE IN THE ROOM a young NICARAGUAN WOMAN, 18, is ta to Claire. She seems to be part of the local press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to get me copies of the  Government inventory lists of all  captured Guerrilla weapons. I want  to know if the guns are Israeli,  Belgian, Russian, Cuban...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guerrillas are not supplied by  anybody from the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine -- give me proof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TELEPHONE OPERATOR CALLS TO CLAIRE through the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Su hija, su hija! Your daughter from  Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire sighs at the bad timing but seems delighted to be  interrupted by her daughter, and brushes aside a Stringer forcing paperwork upon her. Claire takes the phone into a bare, adjacent hallway for some privacy. IN A BARE HALLWAY Claire talks to her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, baby! How are you? (beat) Has Grandmother spoiled you silly by  now? She has? Good. (beats) Yes, I got your letter with the  picture of your new boyfriend. He's  very good looking... but he's a bit  old, isn't he? No? Just how old is  he?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P.O.V. FROM THE TELEX ROOM TO CLAIRE Price knows this is his world, and he wanders outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price bounces along, whistling, "San Francisco." An occas Guardia jeep or taxi rumbles past. He strolls up the walk of a house from which comes a strange, blue glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue walls, bare bulbs, several pictures on the wall, and old woman lying in a hammock. Music in the b.g. Price  approaches her and hands her a $100 bill -- there is a br negotiation of the black market value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in broken Spanish) Cuanto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quince.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Veinte.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diezysiete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs, declaring the negotiation ended, and leaves t room to change the dollar into cordobas. Price idly studi the pictures on the wall:

dialogues.speaker: HANK AARON HITTING HIS 715TH HOME RUN.
dialogues.text: PRICE SMILES AND TURNS RIGHT INTO A SHARP BAYONET mounted a rifle held threateningly by a Guardia soldier. THE SMALL ROOM IS FILLED WITH NATIONAL GUARDS We haven't  heard them enter over the sounds of music and our  preoccupation with the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this? I'm a journalist!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Price pulls a thick passport and press credent from a pocket, handing them to the Officer in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Journalista, journalista!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The officer looks at Price's passport photo, studies it  briefly and takes the passport. He nods. A rifle butt is jammed violently into Price's belly -- he doubles over. The Officer nods, and Price is led away. As the Guard hauls him outside, the OLD WOMAN appears in doorway with a stack of local currency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is led into a dark cell where another PRISONER, 50, lies in street clothes on the floor. The Prisoner is spat upon by the Guards and kicked awake. Price cringes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Padre Puta, Padre Puta, Padre Puta... (in Spanish to Price) Here is a Priest for you to confess  your sins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guards laugh and leave. The Prisoner rises to his fee Price keeps his distance. The Prisoner looks in bad shape

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarillo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price hands him a cigarette and lights it. A long, deep d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Priest? (the man nods) (in broken Spanish) What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) The government accused me of using  the church to hide Rebels and guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Governments are always wrong, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) This time they're right. Who are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Un periodista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Whose side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) I don't take sides. I take pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) No sides?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prisoner Priest looks at Price with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Periodista Puta, todos periodistas  son putas. (All journalists are  whores)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prisoner sits down in the corner ignoring Price who i surprised to be treated so despicably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is led into a lineup of 10 people, all Nicaraguans. The room is narrow and so brightly lit that at first he c his eyes. FIGURES MOVE IN THE SHADOWS A Guardia soldier moves up an down the lineup, stopping to point at a prisoner. In the  line we recognize the WAITER from the Viking Club. Price  speaks to the soldier in a calm, reasoned tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mi amigo -- mala interpretacion, eh?  Periodista, comprende? Famoso. Time  magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier whirls at Price in a rage out of all proporti to Price's tone, shouting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price holds up his hands -- he may be fearless, but he's stupid. The soldier pulls a knife, then pulls his own ton from his mouth, and makes motions with the knife as if cu out his tongue. The message is clear -- Price doesn't spe The soldier walks up to the Waiter and points. The Waiter frightened. Through the shadows we see an officer talking with a civi in a hat. The civilian points to a door. THE WAITER IS LED AWAY THROUGH A DOOR protesting desperat as he goes. The soldier moves to the next prisoner -- he is led away. This repeats itself until the soldier arrive at price.

dialogues.speaker: THE SOLDIER POINTS TO PRICE
dialogues.text: PRICE'S P.O.V. THROUGH THE SHADOWS The civilian is in a  discussion with the officer -- it is clear that his opini affects the decisions. For a moment Price doesn't know wh he's going to be led. The civilian points to a different  door -- it opens -- and Price steps down off the display  rack into a room. THROUGH THE DOOR as Price steps through, the action conti with the other Nicaraguan prisoners. Price looks around  quickly, but the Civilian and Officer are gone. He is qui shown into a bare office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures on the wall of Somoza and the FLAG RAISING AT IW JIMA. Price's cameras and bag sit on a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rumpled elegance is at odds with the brutal surroundings. The door closes. A SENIOR OFFICER ENTERS THE BARE ROOM, and Price addresse him at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soy un periodista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in excellent English) Mr. Price... you must accept our  deepest apologies for the  misunderstanding. Somebody saw you  taking photographs of terrorists  hooligans in the parade and at the  nightclub -- our young officers get  carried away... they're always looking  for traitors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That film is half way to New York by  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, I know... It was all a  misunderstanding... una mala  interpretacion. Your cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Officer reaches for one of Price's cameras and hands to him, but as he does: THE CAMERA DROPS TO THE GROUND AND BREAKS -- SILENCE The  Officer would love for Price to get angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price smiles barely, and refuses to pop off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price puts his cameras in his bag, and as he is shown fro the room he notices a copy of the TIME MAGAZINE WITH ELEP sitting on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is shown to a door, handed over to a soldier, and l outside into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire stands at the main doorway surrounded by GUARDS, a OFFICER, and an unidentified CIVILIAN -- she is arguing w them in rapid Spanish, not allowing them to get in a word

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You throw a journalist in jail -- it  gets in the papers. You walk all  over the same press credentials you  pass out. I demand to speak to someone  in authority or I'll go to Tacho  myself... I don't understand you --  you're big and strong and handsome  but you're not so smart! (beat) You should be trying to seduce us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Senora...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRICE IS SHOWN OUT A DOOR IN THE BACKGROUND and sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hurry toward each other and embrace briefly. The Gua watch it all curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine -- what're you doing here?  These guys are goons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They love being beaten up by a woman (beat) I've been looking for you all night --  why'd they lock you up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk away together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Taking pictures. The  usual. Jazy got me released.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy?! You think there's a story  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh... C.I.A. stories are all alike.  I wanta find Rafael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat) When should we start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure you probably want to do a  little research on the history of  Marcel Jazy's business connections  in the third world countries with  C.I.A. influence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I assumed you'd just look him in  the eye and say "Gimme a break, for  crissakes, Marcel, are you a spy or  aren't you?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcel Jazy stands, drink in hand, looking slightly rumpl in the daylight, slightly older, but more charming and se effacing than his first impression indicated. His two sto Mediterranean style house is in slight disrepair; the gar are scraggly and overgrown. The pool is empty. Jazy addre Price and Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...are you a spy or aren't you, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Spy is such an odd word, Mr. Price...  nobody is a... 'spy'... anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell prefers pictures to words...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to apologize... you're  journalists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're a businessman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A businessman? That sounds good.  Okay, I'm a businessman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was I arrested, and why did you  get me released, and who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks, the questioning comes to a sudden halt as a SPECTACULAR LOOKING WOMAN emerges from the shadows of the house into the light of the courtyard. She is tall, Latin and besides high heels wears only a shiny, high fashion  swimsuit, cut high on the legs. Price, Claire, and Jazy stop to watch as the woman stops look into the empty pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No agua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) No agua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Oh, Marcel! You told me there would  be water in the pool this week!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy leans in very coolly to Price and Claire as he pours extra glass of wine and speaks softly in English again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she dove in, I assure you she  wouldn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carries the glass of wine to the woman, smiling warmly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Miss Panama in  Spanish) Sweetheart, the Guerrillas knocked  out the pumping station on the road  to Masaya, and we must ration water  for the time being. Next week maybe  things will be better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Maybe I should go back to Panama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Maybe you should.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy pushes a lounge chair over to her and hands her a gl of wine. The woman unfolds gracefully into a lounge chair the sun. Very sexy. She reaches for and kisses Jazy's han affectionately -- he kisses her forehead. She feels bette now. Jazy motions for Claire and Price to follow him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pool is visible in b.g. His house, like the pool, is  rumpled and slightly sloppy though it betrays the taste o its occupant -- books everywhere, pictures on the wall,  nothing cheap or tacky but everything is well worn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were arrested because the Guardia  are clowns who specialize in excess.  You were released because I told  them to release you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are not the normal duties of a  businessman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks at them directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they are the normal duties of  a... spy, eh? You win, I'm a spy. (smiles) There, are you happy? I feel better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He refills their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we can relax. You can turn off  your little thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red light of her recorder is on. She smiles slightly, undisturbed, and turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I trust you won't say anything  to hurt me. In some ways I'm a  terrible spy. I used to be much better  at it, but now it seems everyone  knows who I am. I have too many  girlfriends. I like to be  photographed. (beat) I talk too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Claire are almost afraid to speak, afraid to  interrupt this strange performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always talk too much... but my  girlfriends like that... No matter. (pointing to the  swimsuited woman) You know who she is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Miss Panama. Do you know who  that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in love with me. I've got to  get some water in the pool. (beat) And once a week I have lunch with  President Somoza to discuss security  measures against the Sandinista  insurgents, but all he wants to talk  about is Miss Panama... he's worried  about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire interrupts with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he thinks she's seeing another  man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy smiles slightly before confirming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and he assigned me to find out  who the man is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all smile at this complication. Price is impressed.  Jazy changes the subject with fluent and disturbing ease.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all know the Revolutionaries are  going to win, don't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. They don't know how to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all are slightly entertained and glad for the relief Unsure what to say next, Price notices a picture on the w

dialogues.speaker: POOL
dialogues.text: The same picture we saw on the leaflets in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a rumor about this picture.  Some people say you're a genius --  that you invented this scheme.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was lots of people's idea... Have  you been to Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Masaya... they say  the Rebels have hit the cuartel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be nasty there... a  lotta people think Rafael's in the  South. I want to find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, it's not "nasty" yet. Another  week maybe. (beat) You would love Leon. A nice cathedral  and beautiful light... et un peu de  bang-bang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not doing a travelogue, you  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, of course... only I have  heard that Comandante Rafael has  recently had his unit in the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Rafael is near Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's a rumor, what do I know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of Miss Panama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Estoy desemperado!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's lonely!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't let us stand in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job. (beat) You think I talk too much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't wait for an answer, but excuses himself and go out to tend to Miss Panama. P.O.V. OF JAZY AND MISS PANAMA BY THE EMPTY POOL as Jazy  touches her, whispers, and she waves to Claire and Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. Price lathers up with shaving cream for th first time, cleaning up. As he applies the lather he stop and slowly draws a face on the mirror with shaving cream  until he is staring at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RENTED CAR WITH WHITE FLAGS turns onto the road to Leon Price drives, eats, and reads a map. Claire takes the map from him and reads it herself. They seem to enjoy their f moment alone without Alex looking over their shoulder. A  small band-aid is on Price's clean shaven cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you dream about Miss Panama last  night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dreamed about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... so'd you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches out and touches his band-aid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And old war injury flaring up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the tape on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on the deck of the U.S.S. Pueblo  catching some rays when the North  Koreans attacked... took a bullet  right in the chest, but by luck I  had an extra roll of high speed  ektachrome in this pocket right  here... over the heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the bullet ricocheted off the  film, grazed your cheek, and saved  your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard about it?! I was lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PASSING SHOT OF A CLUSTER OF ROADSIDE CROSSES marking a s of graves. Immediately the tone in Claire's voice changes sobered by the reminder of war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did anyone ever die next to you in  combat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F.8 at a sixtieth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an old joke. My question was  serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So was I. (beat) You ever dream about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again their glibness is interrupted by what they came to  see. Even as they joke, they watch the landscape with con REFUGEES ARE STREAMING OUT OF LEON, mostly women and chil some old men, carrying their possessions. Soldiers stand  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm basically a coward, Russell, I  hope you understand that. I hope we  don't get shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: A GUARDIA ROADBLOCK ON A HILL OVERLOOKING THE CITY
dialogues.text: The press car pulls up to a stop. Price and Claire get ou quickly, hand their credentials to a soldier, and open th trunk and the hood. As the car is searched they look down the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: from several places in the town. The sound of gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldier in Spanish) I thought it was quiet here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Quiet? Are you sure you want to go  down there? Not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier laughs at the journalists and hands back the  credentials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You must leave the car here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price speaks in English knowing he can't be understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldier) You thinking of scoring a Toyota?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) No problem -- we leave the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Claire remove their things from the car, and Pr takes the distributor cap as well as the keys. They walk  over and look down the road leading into the city under s MORE REFUGEES EVACUATE THE TOWN -- it is a most uninvitin sight. The plane passes over the town in the distance fir rockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price responds by flashing his light meter in the air, ta a quick, nervous reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful?! Where the fuck we going?  Better light?

dialogues.speaker: PRICE AND CLAIRE WALK SLOWLY INTO LEON
dialogues.text: Looking around warily as they go, they are the only peopl entering the town. Claire speaks softly into her tape rec as they walk in, recording the event without editorializi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...June tenth... the evacuation of  Leon... a woman carries a pig...  signs for the F.S.L.N. are  everywhere... a body...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BODY OF A YOUNG MAN lies ignored on the sidewalk. The continue walking and soon come to:

dialogues.speaker: AN INTERSECTION HELD BY LA GUARDIA TROOPS WITH A TANQUETT
dialogues.text: Price and Claire duck into a doorway, protected in effect the Government soldiers who wait silently, guns ready, ar the corner of a building. We see what they're waiting for A YOUNG SANDINISTA COMES OUT OF A BUILDING a block away,  holding a handgun. Momentarily confused, he begins runnin toward us, toward the soldiers waiting in ambush. The  Guerrilla races quickly to his waiting death, and as he t the corner right into a dozen Guardia troops: THE GUARDIA GUNS OPEN UP ON THE YOUNG GUERRILLA, killing instantly. CLAIRE TURNS HER HEAD AWAY unable to watch.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE RECORDS THE EVENT WITH HIS CAMERA
dialogues.text: THE GUARDIA FOLLOW THE TANQUETTA SLOWLY down the street t the Rebel youth's house. Suddenly the intersection is emp PRICE AND CLAIRE MOVE DOWN A SIDESTREET SLOWLY as: SEVERAL GUERRILLA MUCHACHOS DART OUT OF AN ALLEY with  sharpened sticks, a spear gun, and one home-made gun. The Muchachos hesitate briefly, lost, and see Price. THE MUCHACHOS QUICKLY POSE FOR A PICTURE motioning for Pr to record them. They pose instantly in "tough-guy" postur PRICE TAKES THEIR PICTURE and just as quickly they dart a through a bombed out building. THREE SANDINISTAS LEAP OFF A ROOFTOP and race toward Clai and Price who freeze:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment they aren't sure what this means -- are they trouble? The Sandinistas shove past the two journalists,  pushing open a doorway and disappearing inside. For a mom Price and Claire are alone on the street. THE DOOR OPENS AGAIN SLOWLY and a middle-aged WOMAN appea motioning for them to come inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Sandinistas, dressed half in khaki, half recycl disco, are pleading with a young man, PEDRO, 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You must come and help us... one  more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) No, please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the Sandinistas brings Pedro his rumpled baseball  jersey from another room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) For Leon... for Nicaragua!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro sees Price and Claire and is more interested in the He speaks in broken but understandable English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Americans? Journalists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro lights up, and runs to a shelf where he returns wit baseball he is signing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah! I put my autograph on this ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Pedro! There is no time to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro is more interested in the two Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you get back to the United  States, I want you to give this ball  to Tippy Martinez for me. He is from  Nicaragua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro hands Claire the baseball as the Sandinistas plead  with Pedro for his help. He is more interested in getting the baseball delivered to Tippy Martinez. Claire accepts ball graciously, exchanges awkward glances with Price, an puts it in her shoulder bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Enrique is dead! Roberto has  disappeared! The Guardia has the  church, and we need you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Claire and Price) You come, eh? (to the Sandinistas) Can they come with us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come! Everybody come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the door and open it a crack to look out. P.O.V. THE TANQUETTA PASSES as Soldiers kick open doors a the street. The Sandinistas go to a corner of the room and push a boo shelf out of the way. A large hole has been broken in the wall. They climb through the hole into the living room of the next house; the woman pushes the shelf back over the  hole with great effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family huddles in the corner as the MAN OF THE HOUSE pu back a couch and a hanging blanket, revealing another hol knocked in the wall. The Sandinistas, Pedro, Claire and P scramble through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: all the houses on the block, connecting the homes with a  secret passageway. The six of them race through the house each hole opening and then closing magically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Sandinistas, Pedro, Claire, and Price emerge. A WOMAN, 50, runs the cafe and welcomes them. The SIX crawl as not to be seen from the street; they stop long enough survey the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half a dozen bodies are scattered across the plaza. Other it is empty. P.O.V. SIX GUARDIA SNIPERS IN THE CHURCH TOWER control th plaza. As we watch, they fire off occasional shots in  different directions--there is no way to cross the plaza. THE WOMAN PULLS A TRAY OF "CONTACT BOMBS" from the oven,  home-made grenades that look like muffins on a tray. Pedr grabs one and pretends to bite into it. The Sandinistas s to laugh and catch themselves as Pedro clowns. Claire and Price aren't sure what the "muffins" are and don't respon mostly they are on edge. The contact bombs are put in a s The woman opens a trap door in the floor, and the six of  them climb down a ladder into a tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pedro leads them with a candle through a dark passage und the street. Overhead we hear gunfire. Rats scurry, and wa runs through an open sewer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tapestry rug is pulled away, and Pedro's head appears. climbs out and soon all the party is in the church. A PRI leads them quickly through an immense, nearly. European  interior of ornate altars and burning candles. The small  party is led to a small corner of the sanctuary where a l rickety ladder leads up to the roof.
