THE SANDINISTAS SCRAMBLE UP THE LADDER as it sways. Pedro follows with his sack of contact bombs. Then Price goes u as the Priest holds the ladder. The American is much larg than the Nicaraguans -- the ladder squeaks and sways, and when he is nearly at the top: THE LADDER CRACKS as Price reaches the top and is helped safety. The Priest steadies the ladder now made unsafe an clearly Claire wants to go onto the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) No, please... it's not safe. You  must come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire looks at Price -- she wants to go on the roof but sound of close gunfire settles the dilemma. Claire hurrie off to safety with the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: THREE SANDINISTAS, PEDRO, AND PRICE EMERGE FROM A TUNNEL
dialogues.text: onto a lower level of the cathedral rooftop where a body  lies. They are exposed immediately and automatic weapons  fire opens up on them -- the Sandinistas flatten against wall, quickly becoming separated from Price and Pedro. TWO SANDINISTAS RACE FOR COVER BEHIND A CUPOLA in a move  that is equally daring and foolish. The diversion draws f from the two soldiers. PRICE'S LIGHT METER IS INSTANTLY OUT TAKING READINGS as P huddles with him, curious at this strange act.

dialogues.speaker: TWO GUARDIA MOVE INTO POSITION TO FLUSH OUT THE SANDINIST
dialogues.text: as they hide behind the cupolas. The hidden Third Guerril opens fire killing a Guardia soldier, and the other soldi races for the belltower. As he does: THE SANDINISTAS SEIZE THE MOMENT TO RUSH CLOSER, waving t Pedro who slips along a wall with his bag of bombs. PRICE STARTS TO FOLLOW BUT IS PINNED DOWN BY FIRE and cho to take refuge halfway in an alcove. As fire from both si ricochets all over the rooftop, Price switches camera len seemingly oblivious to the action. PEDRO MEETS ONE OF THE SANDINISTAS in a protected niche a quickly they are unfolding his bag, setting the "muffin b out on the rooftop. THE OTHER TWO SANDINISTAS OPEN HEAVY FIRE and briefly dra heavier fire from the belltower, as: PEDRO PICKS UP A MUFFIN weighing it briefly in his hand,  like a pitcher. He studies the surroundings -- runners on first and third, no outs -- he spits in his left (his pit hand) and rubs it in casually. Pedro crosses himself, goes into an abbreviated pitching  motion, then rears and fires the 'muffin' toward the bell window, exposing himself as he does.

dialogues.speaker: AN EXPLOSION IN THE TOWER
dialogues.text: PEDRO THROWS ANOTHER INTO THE TOWER -- another explosion. A GUARDIA SOLDIER STAGGERS INTO THE WINDOW and a Sandinis drops him with a shot. All is quiet. THE THREE SANDINISTAS CAREFULLY RUSH THE TOWER, looking i and motion to Pedro and Price that all is okay, and as th do: ANOTHER SHOT RINGS OUT -- they whirl around -- Pedro and  Price drop again. A lone Guardia soldier fires at them fr the other tower. A THIRD SANDINISTA DROPS HIM WITH A VOLLEY OF FIRE Again is quiet. PRICE FOLLOWS THE SANDINISTAS TO THE FIRST BELLTOWER and  looks in. FIVE BODIES LIE SCATTERED AND BLOODIED One of the Guerril kicks a couple of them to make sure they are dead. In the corner, one body lies on top of another. Satisfied, the  Sandinistas head for the other tower. PRICE STAYS BEHIND TO TAKE A FEW PICTURES and the ever-pr light meter appears, followed by several quick shots of t bodies. Then Price goes to one of the arched, stone windo He looks out over the city. P.O.V. OF LEON -- DUSK Late in the afternoon now, the fig is over for the day. An occasional gunshot. Smoke rises f scattered places throughout the city. There is new rubble The town is littered with bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man walks in front of it, chanting slowly, rhythmically

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay heridas o muertes aqui? Hay  heridas o muertes aqui? (Are there wounded or  dead here?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a woman drag a body out into the street. The Red C man makes small stacks of bodies. He douses the bodies wi gasoline and sets the pile aflame. Then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hay heridas o muertes aqui?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price watches. He thinks he hears something, then dismiss it. Something else. A voice, almost a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price. You motherfucker, Price, I'm  talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. One of the bodies speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are those bastards... are they  away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price looks out -- the Sandinistas are on the other side the roof. This war gets stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body rolls out from under another body. Blood-splattere smiling, wiping the blood from his face. It is Oates, the mercenary from Africa. He peeks out the window -- the  Sandinistas are on the other side of the roof. He whisper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment they understand that they are there for the  same reason -- they make their livings off war. Oates pee out the window nervously and repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awright, awright -- you're lookin'  good... how ya like Nicaragua?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OATES readies his automatic weapon in case it's needed -- routine. Price doesn't know how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates laughs quickly and softly -- he is tuned into the  strangeness of Price's answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shitload o' greasers though, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OATES AND PRICE SEE THEM, and Oates crawls back under the pile of bodies. THE SANDINISTAS LOOK INTO THE BELLTOWER, all looks quiet, and they motion to Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) It's getting late -- come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Sandinistas, Pedro, and Price are hiding in the shadows of the main church entrance. The Sandinistas are  carefully peeking around the corner, checking out the pla It seems safe. The door opens; the Priest lets Claire out For a moment she looks around to see who's still alive -- the shadows Price looks like one of the Guerrillas. They each other and embrace briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sandinistas seem to relax. The Sandinistas take pride Pedro and pat his left arm for Price and Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: San-dee Koufax, no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si, Koufax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Es mejor que Koufax, eh?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They seem to want approval from the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much better than Koufax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sandinistas slap hands, familiar with the American  gesture. The Six start walking across the plaza away from the church. In the b.g. we see piles of bodies burning; t Red Cross tends to the wounded locals. Spirits are high a they walk. The tiny red light glows on Claire's recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Koufax is okay... but Tippy Martinez,  he is the best... he pitches for the  Baltimore Orioles, and some day I  will be the second man from Nicaragua  to play in the major leagues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Price and Claire) Tippy Martinez had a good fastball,  but Pedro has a curveball and a  screwball that are better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All five of them agree that Pedro is the best; they slap valued arm and relax for the first time all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will give my autographed baseball  to Tippy and tell him in five years  I will be pitching with him, okay?  He better watch out for me, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OATES CHECKS THE CLIP ON HIS RIFLE and looks down into th plaza. OATES P.O.V. TO THE SIX WALKING AWAY He doesn't smile or  joke -- it's all business. He aims the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) It's too dangerous to return to  Managua at night. You should stay at  the house of hammocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Gracias. Can they get into trouble  for keeping us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... you are not combatants. (would rather talk  baseball) The Baltimore team is my team...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOT RINGS OUT, AND PEDRO'S CHEST EXPLODES in front of Sudden panic, rage, confusion -- the Sandinistas whirl an scan the building. P.O.V. OATES RACING ACROSS THE CATHEDRAL ROOFTOP into the night. PRICE GRABS PEDRO'S GUN AND WHIRLS to face the church; hi action is instinctive, angry, and electric with energy. CLAIRE GRABS PEDRO'S ARM AND DRAGS THE BODY to safety, th there is no safety and the body is lifeless. Her actions protective and automatic. THE SANDINISTAS TAKE CONTROL OF THE SITUATION and move  quickly. Two of them fan out to cover the escape. Price  screams in the direction of Oates,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bastard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire drags the body near a bench under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about him?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dispassionately) He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sandinistas survey the cathedral and streets carefull warily, upset at their nonchalance. They know the sniper disappearing into the night, but they continue to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will talk to Pedro's mother. You  must go to the house of the hammocks  if you want to be safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Three Sandinistas fan out toward the church as it get dark. PRICE AND CLAIRE STAND NEXT TO PEDRO, feeling helpless an ineffective. They both look at the body. Price realizes h holding Pedro's gun and places it down next to the body.  Price notices the tiny red light is still glowing on her  tape recorder. He points it out to Claire. She turns it o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN A NEARLY DARK ROOM full of hanging hammocks, Claire si on the floor lit by a low wattage bulb hanging from a cor In another room through a door Price can be seen with a f in the hammock workshop. Claire talks softly into her  recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello sweetheart, this is your mother.  I'm in Leon and I miss you. Don't  worry about me -- it's not dangerous  at all. I guess you can't believe  what you hear on the news. I'll put  this this tape in the mail when I  get back to Managua, but knowing  what the mail service is like, I may  be home before it arrives. I think  about you all the time and hope I  can make it back before you graduate  from Jr. High.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she speaks Price bids the family farewell and comes in the room with Claire where he lies down in a hammock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you and I'll finish this letter  when I get back to the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire lies down on a mat, exhausted, after turning out t light. Several moments pass before Price speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who shot Pedro. I knew somebody  was in the tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell the guerrillas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... then they would've  killed him I guess. I didn't want to  interfere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't an easy choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I made the wrong one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't take any pictures when it  was over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't? (beat) I picked up a gun. Jesus. (beat) Is something happening to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. They lie for a long time in the dark. A light in the house is turned off. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price gets out of the hammock and lies down next to her.  They don't speak. They kiss. She unbuttons his shirt. He  unbuttons her blouse. They undress just enough to begin m love softly, quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first light of dawn strikes Claire's bare torso. PRICE'S LIGHT METER APPEARS AT HER BACK Price takes a rea then moves the meter to her neck, another reading. He mov it down her nude body lit beautifully in the vague light, partially covered with a blanket. He scurries across the room, stark naked, with a camera.  Price begins photographing her. He moves back to her and gently removes the blanket from rest of her body. His actions are quiet and easy. He stop frequently to admire her. Claire lies sleeping nude, except for her socks. Price mo around the room -- picture, picture, picture. CLAIRE WAKES UP SLOWLY and pulls the blanket back over he She opens her eyes and sees Price sitting in a chair seve feet away with his camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: G'morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She realizes what he's been doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout ten frames. Wait'll you see  the pictures -- you look great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her sense of violation is balanced by this notion. For a  moment we sense her attitude can go either way -- outrage some sense of being flattered, however ill conceived. She chooses the latter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet I look great -- give me the  film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After they're printed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll develop them myself -- give it  to me or I'll start taping what you  say in your sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price hands her the film and climbs back under the blanke with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talk in my sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girl's names and F-stops. Terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They curl up together, holding onto each other. A small c crosses the courtyard, peeking at them. A rooster crows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the office. I don't want to go  to work today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The peacefulness is shaken by the roar of an engine close by. A HELICOPTER GUNSHIP PASSES OVER THE COURTYARD They look jolted out of the moment. The war is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price's rental car is a smoking wreck. He and Claire arri and she removes a single, feeble white flag that remains. They study the car briefly and then turn as: A GUARDIA TROOP CARRIER LUMBERS past with a truckload of  refugees behind. They wave the flag and catch a ride with the refugees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex comes out a door chatting with somebody, and passes mini-cam crew, old friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was Matagalpa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bang-bang, Alex... none at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You find anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the press corps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small laugh. They continue on. Alex enters Claire's roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex enters. Nobody there. As he turns to leave he sees s pictures in a stack of papers on her desk. He picks one u CLOSE UP: A PICTURE OF CLAIRE SLEEPING IN LEON It's all o and he knows it. He stares at, even admires, the image. H puts it down and turns to leave as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (awkwardly) How was Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... I'll bet... Claire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex finally acknowledges that it is over with Claire, bu refuses to say it directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of Nicaragua.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been here very long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long enough, lets face it, you were  right... everybody was right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My cheekbones. What do you think of  'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like your cheekbones. Alex, are  you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a face made for television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You decided to go with the network.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex nods, then seems to hit the end of his own resilienc and gets vitriolic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he a good fuck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a simple monologue Alex goes from outrage to acknowled of what he already knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a reasonable question for a  reporter to ask, isn't it?! (beat) I shoulda never come down here, eh?  This is the way it's going to be. (beat) I'll make a shitload of money in  television for just sitting there. (beat) I'm gonna show up to work at  Rockefeller Center every morning and  they're gonna hand me the news with  my coffee and toast. (beat) I shoulda never come down here, eh?  This war down here belongs to you  guys, okay? I'm on tommorrow's plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to take me to the airport?  It's okay. (beat -- resigned) I shoulda never come down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab pulls up. Soldiers stand around everywhere. Price,  Claire, Alex, and the Cabbie get out. The cabbie takes hi bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take this to check in. I'll be right  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price pulls a bottle of wine from his camera bag and sets three styrofoam cups on the cab roof. He hands the cork t Alex and shows him the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sniff this sucker, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex does, and looks at the label.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The C.I.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They toast and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey -- I'll leave you guys alone,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, don't be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're grownups, Russell... (non acerbically) Most of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward smile from Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two wanta happy snap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price makes the motion of taking a picture. They look at with affection, yet astounded again by his inappropriaten

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No happy snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay... (beat) I'll just... be over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wanders away from the car to give them a moment alone, and as he does he pulls the light meter from his pocket,  flipping it on and off nervously without looking at it. H wanders idly toward a Guardia soldier. The soldier gets  nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex considers this -- he understands (whether he wants t or not). THE SOLDIER COMES FACE-TO-FACE with PRICE, WHO BACKS OFF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to soldier) I'm a personal friend of Tacho's. (smiles disarmingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier stops at Tacho's name. Price turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRICE TURNS AGAIN, embarrassed, faces the soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look, huh? (beat) No mire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier, confused, turns away, and as he does:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahh, I'm a chicken, don't worry. (beat) Alex, listen to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within a year you're gonna be one of  the "Ten Most Admired Men in America."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex is amused, Price is serious. The cabbie comes out an Alex heads into the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy and her combo from the Viking Club perform "The Gir From Ipanema" as ONE HUNDRED PRESS MEMBERS and V.I.P.'s s at long tables in the garden. The pleasantness of the  surroundings is countered by the presence of dozens of  SOLDIERS in the background, guarding the house, etc. Visi at the head table are: TWO GENERALS AND THEIR WIVES, MRS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAT. Elsewhere mingling are: JAZY, ISELA, PRICE, REGIS. A elaborate array of food sits on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlooking the gathering from his private living room, S grants Claire her interview. He close the window to muffl the singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late to your own luncheon,  Mr. President -- we can schedule  this for another time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense -- let them wait. We are a  stunning couple, eh? My stomach is  very flat -- I've been working out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are a stunning couple. Mr.  President, you own one fifth of all  the land in Nicaragua, you own the  shipping port, the national airlines,  the Mercedes dealership...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am on a salt free diet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand and leads her to two large portraits ha on a wall -- his parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you always hold hands with  reporters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignores her) This is my mother and father. They  were very special to me. Every Sunday  morning I drive out to the cemetery  and put flowers on their grave. I  think people should know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you care to comment on the  fall of Leon to the rebels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somoza just smiles unaffected by her questions; she knows the game is undaunted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hub Kittle is bending Price's ear in the crowd. Price see ammused and watches the anthem contest as he munches food

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Russell, let's grow up. It's  very easy to fall in love with the  underdog, eh? But there's an upside  and downside to this thing -- just  wanta remind you... this stuff about  a "Revolution of Poets" is crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's great P.R. So what's the  upside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simple. And it could happen. Somoza  destroys the terrorist insurgents,  rebuilds the country, shitcans the  purveyors of excess, stabilizes the  cordoba, and is finally beloved as  the savior of Nicaragua. (beat) Our pal. Got a smoke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price gives him a cigaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the downside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Commies take over the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's simple, and Hub is pleased with his presentation. A  SOLDIER moves through the crowd looking quite out of plac finds Hub and hands him a note. Hub reads it, seems delig and excuses himself from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, gentlemen, but the war  may be over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Regis look at each other strangely -- what's he talking about? They shrug, Regis bites into a papaya, and Hub hurries inside. Price and Regis watch the singer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My people love me. My stomach is  flat. Did I say that already? No  matter. It is flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are reports that the Guardia  operates a torture chamber at  Coyotepe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somoza ignores the question and reopens the window, flood the room with the Tony Bennett classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like this song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since the earthquake in 1972 destroyed  half of Managua, over three hundred  million dollars in foreign relief  aid have poured into the country,  yet nothing has been re-built. It is  said that the money has gone into  your pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the press, I really do. Some  of my best friends are journalists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, Brazil, and  Panama are reportedly on the verge  of breaking off diplomatic relations  with your regime. Would you comment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HUB KITTLE AND AN OFFICER BURST INTO THE ROOM interruptin the interview. Something has happened. Somoza initially l out at them -- the first time we've seen him lose his coo then recovers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) I am busy! Get out of here at once  or I'll put my foot up your ass!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OFFICER seems familiar with these tirades and grabs S by the arm, whispering into his ear. Somoza seems delight with the news and turns to Hub for confirmation. Hub nods

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Claire) I'm sorry to have to conclude this  most pleasant encounter, but something  has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Somoza leaves the room with the Officer and Hub, Hub t to Claire to squeeze in one final P.R. stroke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you about his parents in  the graveyard, the flowers and all  that? (she nods) Good, good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire is left alone momentarily in Somoza's room. A sold enters and accompanies her outside to the luncheon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Claire comes outside, there is a flurry of activity at the head table. TWO OFFICERS hastily set up an easel with large military-topographical map of Nicaragua. A SOLDIER  takes the microphone from the Singers -- the music grinds an inglorious halt -- and carries it to the head table. Price spots Claire and makes a "What's all this about?"  motion. Claire holds out her palms and shrugs -- she does know. All attention is quickly focused on the head table, as: PRESIDENT SOMOZA MAKES A GRAND ENTRANCE FLANKED by Hub Ki and an Officer. He seems suddenly in unusually good spiri Hub taps the mike -- it works -- he motions for Somoza to come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends... this gathering was not  intended to be a press conference as  much as a... "get-together"... but I  have just been handed a piece of  news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somoza plays the moment with theatrical elan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael is dead. (beat) He has been killed in an ambush in  the Cordillera mountains of the  Jinotega district.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somoza points to a spot on the map as do his Officer. THE PRESS TABLE IS SHAKEN FROM ITS NONCHALANCE and severa journalists immediately leap to their feet to question hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President! Mr. President!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please my friends -- no questions. A  press release is being prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somoza hands the mike to an aide who returns it to the mu stand. Almost immediately the music begins again. AT THE PRESS TABLE there is some confusion over the  announcement. Some journalists hurry off to file the stor others just sit. Price seems alarmed by the announcement, confused. Slightly wired, he listens to Regis and OTHER  JOURNALIST discuss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got Rafael? You believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every six months Tacho gives this  speech -- maybe they finally lucked  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAIRE TRIES TO CORNER HUB KITTLE who is heading back ins Hub disappears inside, Claire pressing after him. JAZY APPROACHES PRICE and leans in as if sharing a confid IN the b.g. the luncheon is breaking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, excuse me... but I've just  been put in a rather embarrassing  position. (hesitates) Mrs. Somoza would like her picture  taken with Miss Panama. In color?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price throws his camera bag over his shoulder, pulls out camera, and follows Jazy. They walk toward the head table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell could Tacho find Rafael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, please... I have my hands  full...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Somoza and Miss Panama are waiting as Price and Jazy arrive. Price is automatically switching camera lenses, b he continues to grill Jazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tacho, Tacho... venga, por favor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Jazy exchange glances as Somoza reluctantly joi the portrait. SOMOZA POSES WITH HIS WIFE AND HIS MISTRESS ON EACH ARM a Price flashes a light meter under their noses, then backs off to take the picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Tacho lying again? They did kill  him, didn't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price takes a picture, Somoza wants to leave and Jazy wou just as soon have this awkward moment over with, but:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more, please! Una mas, por favor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly they pose again, and Price grills Jazy who is trapped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We help each other, right? Could you  move your girlfriend into the sun...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy moves Miss Panama slightly, returning to Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Rafael alive or dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the posers) Just one more -- thank you. (to Jazy) I thought you knew everything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Somoza holds an interminable pose, Jazy launches into speech, keeping his voice low enough so Tacho cannot hear

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I know, eh? Tacho needs a  victory very badly... he needs to  prove to Jimmy Carter that he is  still winning. He thinks Rafael's  death is the proof he needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carter don't need proof. He just  sent twenty-five million in new arms  to Tacho. (to posers) I'm sorry... almost got it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... the arms shipment has been  delayed in New Orleans because Jimmy  is getting nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The State Department's gonna pull  the plug on Tacho?! Pardon my French --  but whose fucking side are you on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jazy and Price motion for the posers to move a step over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I work for everybody. If there is  a transition of power, I facilitate  a relationship with the new people.  If there is not, I facilitate the  status quo. (beat) Either way, I facilitate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I send messages to Jimmy and I tell  him that the Revolution is a flood  that cannot be stopped but it can be  controlled... nobody listens... I  can't even get a little water in my  pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rough ain't it. Thank you everybody,  very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price smiles to Somoza, Mrs. Somoza, and Miss Panama. Som hurries off from his uncomfortable position at last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think Rafael is dead. I'm  gonna find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he's very handsome. (beat) It would make a wonderful picture,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rental station wagon covered with press flags races alo Inside the car are the British crew -- Regis drives -- an Price and Claire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A city of about 50,000 located on the side of a hill. The car pulls slowly into the base of the town into a clearin with assorted vehicles -- Red Cross, La Guardia, Press. T car moves slowly as its occupants survey the town, until pulls alongside a Red Cross truck that has broken down. P sticks his head out the window to ask instructions of a R WORKER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Con permiso -- who controls what  today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) The Sandinistas hold the hills, the  Guardia has everything else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we find the guerillas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (points) Va alli, dos o tres cuartos, doble  la esquina al francotirador.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go two or three blocks and turn right  at the sniper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regis and his crew don't like this at all. Price points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can drop us off.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROAD INTO MATAGALPA
dialogues.text: A gradual uphill grade -- the press car moves slowly. Gua are on both sides of the street, as the car stops at the  corner, directly beneath the sniper tower. They all look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not looking for the guerillas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let us out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car stops, the door opens, and:

dialogues.speaker: A WALL NEARBY IS RIDDLED WITH BULLET HOLES AS THEY CLIMB
dialogues.text: OUT, so they climb back in quickly. P.O.V. A SOLDIER HOLDS OUT HIS ARMS AS IF TO SAY, "accide

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lo siento! (I'm sorry!)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldier seems sincere, but they don't want to take a  chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go one more block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAR MOVES DEEPER INTO MATAGALPA, gradually moving amo tanquettas patrolling the streets, coming to a barricade  which they manuever past as Guardia soldiers look at them strangely. The car turns around -- it has come too far. A GUARDIA OFFICER SIGNALS FOR THEM TO GET OUT but the ide doesn't appeal to Regis and he whirls around, panicking  slightly, and heads off in the other direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just wanted to see credentials,  for crissakes, what're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE BARRICADE OFFICER SPEAKS IN A WALKIE TALKIE to a squa leader a couple of blocks away as the car approaches. THE SECOND OFFICER WHISTLES FOR THE CAR TO STOP but it sp up.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: GLASS and Regis panics, hitting the floorboard and the ca suddenly screeches around a corner, racing through Mataga The car squeals around corner after corner blindly, into:

dialogues.speaker: A GUARDIA BARRICADE AS A FUSILADE OF SMALL ARMS FIRE RING
dialogues.text: OUT The windshield is totally destroyed now, and: THE OCCUPANTS OF THE CAR CROUCH LOW as the car races. Pri and Claire scream at Regis to stop, but it's too late. THE CAR SCREECHES INTO REVERSE as Regis tries to see out back window and Price, out of necessity operates the foot pedal with his hand. The car smokes into an intersection sees: AN OPEN BLOCK AHEAD -- no Guardia are visible, so the car races down the open block and as it comes to an intersect

dialogues.speaker: A SHERMAN TANK COMES AROUND THE CORNER FACING US
dialogues.text: Several times larger than a tanquetta -- it dwarfs us and everything around it. Its giant gun faces us head on. THE PRESS CAR SCREECHES TO A HALT, and everyone scrambles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Periodista, periodista, periodista!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mini-cam equipment is dropped as the British crew  scrambles to safety against a building. Price and Claire up on opposite sides of the street. Silence -- the huge and silent tank is deciding what to d THE TURRET SWINGS SEVERAL DEGREES TO ONE SIDE and lowers the scattered journalists freeze.

dialogues.speaker: A THUNDEROUS ROAR
dialogues.text: leaving a huge crater and not a trace of the expensive qe CLAIRE STARTS LAUGHING, FRIGHTENED, nervous and amused.

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN THROWS A CONTACT BOMB FROM A WINDOW AT THE TANK T
dialogues.text: tiny bomb makes a pitiful explosion, hopelessly ineffecti

dialogues.speaker: THE TANK SWINGS ITS TURRET TOWARD THE HOUSE AND OPENS FIR
dialogues.text: and the wall of the house crumbles quickly as a family  scrambles to the rooftop of a neighboring house. Their ho is destroyed in a second. LA GUARDIA TROOPS APPEAR AND BEGIN FIRING TOWARDS Claire Price, who turn to see: SANDINISTA ARMY REGULARS RUNNING DOWN THE HILL alongside homemade local guerillas. This is the first time we've se the F.S.L.N. regular army in their camouflaged khaki dres THE GUARD TAKES A POSITION TO FIGHT IT OUT and Claire and Price are caught in a cross-fire, pinned to walls on each street side. PRICE PUSHES THROUGH A DOOR TO SAFETY and looks back: CLAIRE IS TRAPPED OUTSIDE pounding on a door that doesn't open. She tries another -- no luck. She curls up in a doo making herself as small as possible as bullets rip the wa around her.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Several youthful guerillas are pushing it. THE BUS COMES FLYING DOWN THE HILL TOWARD THE TANK Severa hundred feet away, it gathers speed toward us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A YOUTH at the wheel props a board under the steering whe and races to the back as ANOTHER YOUTH opens the door as bus races past Claire toward the tank. THE TWO YOUTHS LEAP OUT THE BACK DOOR where they tumble i the dirt just before:

dialogues.speaker: THE BUS SMASHES INTO THE TANK AND EXPLODES
dialogues.text: GUARDIA SOLDIERS SHOOT THE TWO YOUTHS before they get awa as: GUERILLAS APPEAR ON EVERY ROOFTOP opening heavy fire on L Guardia.

dialogues.speaker: GUARDIA TROOPS RETREAT QUICKLY ON FOOT AND IN TANQUETTAS
dialogues.text: THE SHERMAN TANK TRIES TO DISLODGE ITSELF FROM THE BUS bu cannot, and drags the bus with it as it backs down the hi PRICE RUNS OUT TO CLAIRE and huddles with her. She is sha but unhurt. SANDINISTAS ARE EVERYWHERE, moving into Matagalpa as Pric and Claire move past several bodies to higher ground. SANDINISTA BARRICADES ARE ON EVERY CORNER where women ser food to their men. Claire and Price wander through,  momentarily disoriented. A small boy runs through the str kicking a soccer ball, occasionally avoiding a body. He r right up to them and speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busca triquitraques?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow him up a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE NEIGHBORHOOD IS TOTALLY SANDINISTA and several gueril are at the door. The boy speaks to one of the guards, and they are admitted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY ARE SEARCHED IMMEDIATELY, asked to put down their ge asked for credentials, and led down the hallway of a hous that is very American middle class. ANOTHER SOLDIER WITH RIFLE detains them momentarily befor showing them into a room used as a Revolutionary Command  office. ISELA STANDS IN MILITARY FATIGUES talking to her Sandinis colleagues. Clearly she commands respect and makes decisi She finishes and turns to Claire and Price in a very  businesslike way, never acknowledging directly that they  have met before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are looking for Rafael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are somewhat taken aback at her directness and  information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. If it's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why we're here... exactly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Price doesn't do anything before  announcing it first in the bar. (beat) It's a good story. You'll be more  famous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old truck chugs up a series of cutbacks through rough  terrain. The truck has no hood, and a BOY sits on the fen pouring oil from a series of Folgers cans into a funnel s permanently into the engine. Underneath, dangling cans ca the oil as it flows through. Price, Claire and FOUR ARMED SANDINISTAS sit in the back. ISELA rides in front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ISELA, CLAIRE, PRICE AND THE FOUR HIKE into increasingly  inaccessible terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavily guarded but very mobile, the camp consists of per 100 Soldiers, women preparing food, several tents. Price Claire attract attention as they enter. PRICE STOPS AND LOOKS AROUND THE CAMP CLOSELY seeming to  take it all in. He's been in many similar camps, countrie wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael's tent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price doesn't answer but continues taking it all in, and  ISELA shouts to them to continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venga, companeros. (Come, comrades.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY CONTINUE INTO THE CAMP, BUT PRICE STOPS AGAIN Someth has caught him, his sixth sense, a feeling -- he refuses walk further for the moment. No glibness, just coolness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price looks around, speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire looks around quickly. There is no evidence to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can smell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slightly exasperated) Venga por favor! Alli!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue into the camp -- now Claire looks around  nervously. Price mutters a half laugh, softly and strange as they are led to a makeshift table and offered food. In the b.g. Isela enters one of the tents. PRICE AND CLAIRE SIT DOWN TO EAT and Price continues scan the camp as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead. I know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did they bring us all the  way here to see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know. P.O.V. FOUR FIGURES/CONFERRING IN FRONT OF A TENT Isela  emerges and joins them. The others are: THE PRIEST FROM L

dialogues.speaker: A BUSINESSMAN WHOM WE SHOULD RECOGNIZE FROM EARLIER SCENE
dialogues.text: AND COMMANDANTE CINCO, dressed in camouflaged khaki. ISELA WALKS OVER TO CLAIRE AND PRICE after talking with t others. She brings COMMANDANTE CINCO with her. They sit d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Commandante Cinco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all shake hands. Isela begins at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today we took Matagalpa. Leon is  about to fall, and Masaya. And next  week we could be in Managua but it  is still possible to lose. (beat) In the last days of our final  offensive the people of Nicaragua  must know that Rafael is alive and  well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Queremos un fotografia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need a photograph. (beat) Come with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tent is filled with Sandinista officers and soldiers  standing and sitting around. RAFAEL'S BODY LIES ON A TABLE The shirtless upper torso  propped slightly upright, still wearing glasses, the figu of Rafael is distinctly non-heroic. He is slightly overwe slightly balding, but as he lies there surrounded by his  men, the the glow of lanterns, he looks almost alive. Price and Claire look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usted es un fotografo magnifico. (beat) Queremos que vive. (You are a great  photographer. Make  him alive.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price laughs -- the request is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Claire) Why is he laughing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cinco steps forward -- his presence commands attention. H delivery is forceful but not emotional. As he begins to s Price stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) We have momentum, but many more lives  will be lost. Even Washington is  starting to admit that the butcher  Somoza is not loved by his people.  They have detained twenty-five million  dollars in new arms shipments for  Somoza at an airfield in Florida  until they find out if Rafael is  alive or dead. We know about these  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses briefly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Washington thinks Rafael is dead,  they will ship the arms to Somoza.  Do you understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (without enthusiasm) Commandante... Soy un periodista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CINCO attacks that defense with new vigor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has nothing to do with journalism --  there is more to the world than  journalism. We are going to end this  war with you or without you. (beat) People don't really believe in Rafael --  they believe in the idea of Rafael,  no? Because for now the idea of Rafael  is enough for the people of Nicaragua.  When the war is over -- none of this  matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRICE hesitates, his manner devoid of its usual cockiness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do things... like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough lives have been lost already. (beat of empathy) It's difficult, I know -- but you  must do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMMANDANTE CINCO PLACES AN ARM ON PRICE'S SHOULDER and s in broken English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the morning, eh? When there's  better light!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price lies on his back on a table. Claire sits in a chair lantern is on the table. His reclining body is not unlike Rafael's. He plays with a camera without looking at it,  turning it slowly, removing and replacing a lens. He's ne been this calm, this unmoving. Claire, however, moves around the tent like a caged anima like Price normally is. She smokes. She's nervous and wir

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spend my whole life separating how  I feel from how I think and what I  see from what I say -- that's called  journalism, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's disciplined. It civilized. It  involves distinctions. I'm great at  distinctions. I wish I wasn't so  good at them. Sometimes I envy you --  you don't make any -- it's very  convenient. (beat) The only time I don't worry about  all those things is when I'm with my  daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or when you're in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! (beat -- changes  direction) My job is to find a story, then tell  a story -- whatever it is -- because  I believe that if enough people hear  enough stories then somehow, through  information alone, we all have a  better chance to survive. (beat) I believe in information. (beat) That's a very romantic streak I have  running through me -- maybe it's a  weakness. Information is good --  lack of information is bad. Simple,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're God damn right it's not. (beat) You take that picture you'll take it  for all the right reasons -- I  understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fiddles with the cameras.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine for you. But do I go  back and say I interviewed Rafael?  Do I go back and say I missed the  biggest story of the war? Or do I  say Rafael was stone cold dead --  that's the information, isn't it? Or  do I say he entertained us all in  his inimitably charismatic manner  around the ol' revolutionary campfire? (beat) Can we throw up our arms and say we  fell in love with the querillas  because their cause was...  sympathetic? (beat) Journalists don't fall in love. (beat) Which story do you want me to tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what you want to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, what the fuck are we doing  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be here. (beat) With you. (beat) What do you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want this war to end. (beat) I'm not going to tell the world that  Rafael is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Claire lies down on the cot. Exhausted but high. Price gets off the table and goes to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think so much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets on the cot with her. They kiss deeply, passionate and begin making love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMP IS COMING TO LIFE as the flap opens on Price's t and he looks out. He raises his camera and starts taking  pictures of: A WOMAN COOKING OVER A FIRE AS A BUSINESSMAN LOOKS ON, a  face we recognize from earlier in Managua -- FREEZE FRAME

dialogues.speaker: ISELA COMING OUT OF ANOTHER TENT
dialogues.text: PRICE RISES AND LOOKS AROUND THE CAMP, wandering over to large can where he drinks some water. CLAIRE EMERGES FROM THE TENT and watches Price head over a shaded area with his cameras.

dialogues.speaker: SANDINISTAS GATHERED AROUND A TABLE
dialogues.text: Their backs are toward us as he adjusts seating positions and rearranges items that have been provided for the tabl He takes a light reading and moves quickly into position. Price raises his camera.

dialogues.speaker: A TABLEAU OF RAFAEL, CINCO, AND SOLDIER
dialogues.text: They sit at a table studying a map, a copy of La Prensa i displayed -- the headlines declare that RAFAEL IS DEAD an featuring a photo of Somoza at the luncheon as he points a map of the country. For an instant Rafael looks alive - FREEZE FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Claire are sitting on top of a Red Cross truck it heads through Sebaco. Soldiers from La Guardia are  everywhere. As the truck moves through the village, somet catches Price's eyes: OATES STANDS AGAINST A WALL IN COMMAND OF A SQUADRON Two  whores and several troops sit against a wall. As the truc passes, Oates waves casually, with emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red light in the bathroom as Price pulls several photo pr from the bath and plasters them wet against the mirror. PHOTO OF RAFAEL IN THE CAMP, and he looks very much alive He pulls more shots from the bath: THE PRIEST FROM LEON, BUSINESSMAN, COMMANDANTE CINCO AND ISELA. He dries them o and hides them with their negatives under a pile of equip He picks up the shot of Rafael and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of muchachos in masks, baseball caps, and bandana race through the streets carrying a photo blow-up of Rafa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The newspaper headline sits on Jazy's desk as Jazy studie it unemotionally. We hear Miss Panama's voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marcel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spins on his chair as she glides in modeling a new dre She spins magically for him -- he blows her a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small private plane flies through a canyon, dwarfed by spectacular landscape. Hub Kittle works the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two MASKED GUERILLAS hold a gun to the head of a pilot. A large sack is crammed into the tiny compartment with them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane flies in low over the town and suddenly: THE SKY IS FILLED WITH LEAFLETS that flutter to the groun Townspeople, bewildered at first, pick up the papers to s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOCAL RESIDENTS RAISE THEIR FISTS IN SALUTE to the plane it disappears into the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Journalists are gathered to watch the fighting which is n on the outskirts of Managua. Price stands to the side cas taking pictures of Journalists taking pictures of the war Hub Kittle floats around providing drinks and P.R. P.O.V. A PUSH-PULL AIRPLANE MAKES BOMBING PASSES on the  capitol. Columns of smoke rise throughout the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the smoke in frame?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moves the camera  slightly) We got the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAIRE STANDS TO THE OTHER SIDE with binoculars watching. She accepts a drink from Hub and speaks into her tape dec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a steel gray July sky... start  again... under a gray steel Managuan  sky... scratch it... In an  extraordinary development in Managua,  President Anastazio Somoza has ordered  the Air Force to begin bombing his  own capitol, under a sky... fuck  it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She fires down the drink and puts down the mike. She pick up the binoculars again and, glancing below, is shocked:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts into the hotel, glances up, and they see each o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price sees Alex at the same time. Alex waves to both of a he heads into the hotel. Price and Claire look at each ot Claire sits down at a table, stunned to see Alex. Price  commandeers a waiter and joins her with a fresh tray of  drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Scotch, please... (he nods) Double.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price joins her as other journalists jockey for position the railing. He is equally upset and confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALEX COMES THROUGH THE DOOR with a couple journalists, se Price and Claire and comes over to join them. A polite ki on Claire's cheek, a handshake for Price. A moment of  awkwardness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On what?! The Washington Post, the  Times, networks, wire services --  everybody's picked up the picture.  It's fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervously) Well, yes... it's fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unsure silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came back because of Russell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... the whole fucking East Coast  is falling in love with Rafael --  they were sure he was dead this time.  Somebody wants to do a musical about  him and his mug's on every T-shirt  in Central Park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex enjoys the lunatic mixture of politics and popular  culture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's bigger than Farrah  Fawcett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire and Price struggle to enjoy this supremely  uncomfortable moment. It's not easy to enter the game. Cl attempts to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look good. Things're okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm happier in New York, sure, things  are great. You guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific... now... I'm a little slow  here, Alex... what exactly did you  come back for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more games. Alex addresses Price with conviction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great story. (beat) I want to talk to Rafael... and you're  the only man in the world that can  take me to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price's and Claire's hearts sink. They look at each other Alex, despite his reluctance to return to Nicaragua, seem genuinely enthused about the possible story. Before Price Claire respond, Hub Kittle notices Alex and comes over wi a tray of drinks, extending genuine greetings to the Seni Correspondent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex! Couldn't stay away, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fresh round of drinks are put on the table. The sound bombs ripping the capitol are the only thing we hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire and Price now have adjoining rooms. She is staring out the window as he comes in. The mood is strained.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to tell Alex what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell him. He deserves to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't owe him anything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We owe him that! (beat) He got you started in this business...  he covered for your missed deadlines  and made excuses for your  unprofessional attitude before the  world fell in love with your  pictures... (beat) Before kids fresh out of journalism  school were rushing off to any war  they could to interview bullets and  take pictures of bodies -- like Price! (beat) He took care of you before you were  hot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. She's hitting home but he doesn't want to acknow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wouldn't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Nicaragua you wouldn't  understand. I'm not sure I exactly  understand. (beat) What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something calculating in Price's tone, this is n the fearless, boyish innocent anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Alex to find Rafael --  we'll go to Sebaco on the road to  Matagalpa -- the Guardia heavily  control the area and they're scared  right now -- they'll never let us  through. We won't be able to get  near Rafael. Alex will understand --  and we'll turn around and drive back  without a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire is disturbed at this compounding of the lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about lies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. They are co-conspirators and they know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to tell him either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price's white flagged newly rented press car streaks alon overtaking an ox cart. A guardia convoy is going the oppo direction, back toward Managua. Alex looks out of the car with interest--he hasn't been to the front line for sever wars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We may not be able to find him,  y'know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got supreme confidence in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car is on fire by the side of the road. Price flies pas Alex watches curiously. Several people stand around the c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claire looks good, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody looks good in the tropics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex isn't sure how to respond to this curious reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I haven't been able to find  Isela since coming back, you're going  to have to translate for me -- what  the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is nervous, wired, on edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex... I love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex takes this calmly -- it's not exactly new informatio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she 'thinks' she loves you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's past the thinking stage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex looks at the passing scenery -- he's in no hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to know something -- it  probably doesn't matter in the great  final scheme of things... but I'm  interested... (beat) Did you ever lay a hand on her before  she left me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes! (beat) Alex -- we're friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is something desperate in his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Alex are ordered out of their car by a very  unfriendly Guardia soldier. He is ordered to put down his camera bag. The hood and trunk are opened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Venga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are led to a shed by the roadside, A TIRE REPAIR SHO where they sit down in an oily, dusty shack. They watch t soldiers: P.O.V. THE SOLDIERS TEARING UP THE RENTAL CAR, pulling of door panels, looking for weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you go through a few rental  cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I put this in your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRICE AND ALEX JERK TO LIFE at the sound of screaming in distance. A volley of gunfire follows. Price moves quickl into an adjoining shed and looks through a crack in the w P.O.V. AN EXECUTION SQUAD IN A FIELD as several bodies ar being hauled away. Two soldiers reload their guns. PAN to figure moving behind a wall -- OATES.

dialogues.speaker: PRICE HURRIES THROUGH THE SHACKS TOWARD THE EXECUTION WAL
dialogues.text: as Alex calls to him and hurries after -- Price is single minded. As he moves through the shacks we hear another vo of fire, and Price bursts into a clearing to see:

dialogues.speaker: PRICE STEPS INTO THE CLEARING
dialogues.text: They look at each other for several beats before anyone  speaks. Oates is slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pictures, eh? Might look bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates smiles half-way; Price looks around at the bodies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get paid by the body or by the  hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get paid the same way you do. What  the fuck you doin' in Sebaco -- this  place's about to blow... ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have to nail Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Pedro?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex arrives and tries to pull Price back -- at the same  time he sees the bodies and is sickened at the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A body is carried through and loaded on a truck. Oates's  tone is one of explanation rather than defense, very matt of-fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a motherfucking war goin'  on, pal... lotta sad stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price mumbles and wanders to the next truck a few feet aw and as he sees it he stops short, speechless. He points:

dialogues.speaker: THE BODIES OF THE PRIEST FROM LEON AND THE BUSINESSMAN,
dialogues.text: figures we saw at Rafael's camp, sit in the back of the t They are splattered with blood and lifeless. Price is sha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why them? Why them?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates has to look to see who he's talking about, and Pric loses his cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't suck no dick, man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRICE GRABS OATES AND PUSHES HIM BACKWARDS but Oates resp like an animal. The two men go down in a heap and lash ou at each other in the dust. Their fighting is largely  ineffective, though very physical, until Oates asserts hi and knocks Price against a wall, breaking free to pick up his automatic rifle that he handles with one hand and sho it into Price's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd prefer not splattering your brains  in a dump like this -- I got  priorities. (to Alex) Guy wants to be a hero, pops, get  him outta here before he's a number. (beat) Be a shitty little town to buy it  in. (beat) Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, let's get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Oates) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's got a sense of humor, old man. (beat) Got any dope? Tough place to find  decent dope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them? C'mere. You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leads them under an awning nearby where a couple soldi sit. A small table, some weapons, two shallow boxes, food beer. Oates rummages around to find what he wants, and pu out: A HANDFUL OF PHOTOGRAPHS, mostly snapshots, odd sizes, wi names written on them. He sifts through them quickly and see an assortment of photographs of Nicaraguans. He finds what he's looking for and holds up: PRICE'S PHOTOGRAPH OF THE PRIEST AND THE BUSINESSMAN, the picture taken in Rafael's camp, blown up, cropped, and  identified. The faces are circled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your mug shows up in this box...  and ya try to make it through  Sebaco... I owe yer ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This information hits Price in the gut, and he is seized  with fear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gives you the pictures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this, an interview? I ain't  that dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price turns, he doesn't want to face it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off the record... some pachuco gives  'em to me. Ain't none of my business,  but I heard he gets 'em from a Frog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates pulls another picture from a different box and hold it up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex grabs Price and heads back toward the roadblock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatya' expect? We're the ones gettin'  our butts kicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price hangs a U-turn at the roadblock and heads back to  Managua. He drives crazily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some-motherfucker-took-my-fucking- pictures-I-don't-fucking-know-what- happened! (beat) Fuck me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you ship the film to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I developed it in my room. (pleads) Jesus Christ, Alex?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. The car races.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow down. (compassionately) It wasn't your fault if somebody  stole your stuff...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex doesn't force the issue, nor does he understand it  entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Rafael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer -- the car races back to Managua. Alex stares a Price trying to figure out what is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAID IS CLEANING HIS ROOM which is the usual disaster.  Price enters, just returned, and quickly looks for his  negatives under the equipment where he had hidden them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Algo no esta aqui. Fotografias. (Something is not  here. Photographs.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Everything's always a mess here. You  should be neater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negativos, negativos!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid shrugs -- Price is crazy anyway, and: CLAIRE WALKS INTO THE ROOM She too looks shaken. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commandante Cinco's body was just  found on the road to Matagalpa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The maid starts crying. They look at her helplessly as sh sobs, 'Cinco, Cinco...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cab takes them through the increasingly nervous city. L Guardia troop trucks are everywhere -- things seem more  hurried. A hunting rifle sits in the cabbie's lap. They g out and knock on Jazy's door. GUARDIA SOLDIERS WATCH THEM FROM A DISTANCE, a developmen that Price and Claire are aware of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it's Jazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oates said it was a Frog. How many  Frenchmen you know around here? Jazy  ain't 'facilitating' shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price is impatient. He looks around nervously -- the Guar are out of view -- and he slides a knife into the latch,  jimmying the lock. The door opens slowly -- an alarm goes off. Price and Claire duck inside quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price, momentarily comfortable with the danger, responds  quickly and finds the alarm wire running along the door j LA GUARDIA TROOPS NEARBY HEAR THE ALARM and head toward  Jazy's. INSIDE THE HOUSE PRICE FINDS THE ALARM BOX which he pries open and expertly pulls two wires. The alarm stops. Immediately they begin going through drawers and cupboard She pulls out some harmless snapshots of Miss Panama, rep them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we looking for negs or prints?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They find nothing downstairs. The look up at the sound of distant gunfire. Suddenly: Loud banging at the front door -- La Guardia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look around warily, hungrily -- they know something wrong. BACK INSIDE THE HOUSE we hear the shouting soldiers, bang Price and Claire look at each other, and the camera bag.  Claire points upstairs to Price, to the door for herself. Russell grabs the bag and bounds quickly upstairs. Claire goes to the front door, shaking nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que quiere? (What do you want?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donde esta senor Jazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No esta aqui.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Que quienes? (Who are you?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Una novia suya. (A girlfriend of his.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers look at each other curiously and push open t door to look in the house without entering -- respectful Jazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: El hombre tiene muchas novias, eh? (The man has many  girlfriends, no?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soldiers laugh and peer into the room. Claire forces door closed on them, teasing slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid to make a mistake with one of Jazy's sweethearts,  they don't press the issue. The door closes shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLAIRE sighs with frightened relief and hurries upstairs join Price. JAZY'S BEDROOM as she enters. A rumpled bed, a spilled wi glass -- a pleasant mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell? (no answer) Russell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door off the bedroom is open -- light spills out. Clair stops cold at what she sees: PRICE STANDS IN A ROOM FULL OF PHOTOGRAPHS Hundreds of  pictures of all sizes, photographic equipment, an enlarge cameras and lenses, etc. Pictures of Sandino, newspaper  photos, snapshots. P.O.V. OF RUSSELL'S PHOTOGRAPHS FROM RAFAEL'S CAMP croppe and blown up -- Commandante Cinco, the Priest of Leon, th Businessman, Isela. Photographs of other slain rebel lead The pictures include faces that have been circled with na written in -- exactly as in the pictures Oates possessed. They are both stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THEY HURRY DOWNSTAIRS and as they get to the front door - the sound of somebody opening it. They freeze. THE DOOR OPENS AND MISS PANAMA ENTERS She smiles and gree them in a friendly, aloof manner, and continues toward th waterless pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Price and Claire return the greeting and continue out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they emerge, Claire tears a white cloth in half and ti it to a stick, handing half to Price who does likewise. An earth mover goes past, a Guardia soldier at the wheel. More soldiers cling to the machine, their guns at the rea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to talk to Alex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think our flags are big enough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flags held high, they move nervously down the street into the ominous silence of the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex, Price, and Claire get out of a cab and approach a l statue of Somoza on horseback, surreally lit by floodligh in the center of a traffic circle. Four Guardia Soldiers visible on the sidewalk in the b.g. drinking with two wom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is what I want to show you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drove through three roadblocks a  half hour before curfew so you could  show me a statue of Tacho.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Tacho. It's Mussolini. Tacho  went to Italy to commission a statue  of himself, he found a warehouse  full of Il Duces on horseback, got a  great deal on one of 'em -- brought  it back and switched heads. (beat) Ya can't tell, can ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Alex knows Price too well -- it's a great story that's not why they're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think what he's trying to say --  what we're trying to say -- is that  things aren't exactly what they seem  to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they don't "seem" to be that  great so I can't wait for this one... (mocks silliness) Hey, here we are! Two guys in the  tropics in love with the same dame...  bullets flying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex! That's not why we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? I left the country because  of him... (points to Price) ...and I came back because of him... (beat) And now the cutest couple in town  has me looking up a horse's ass on a  midnight tour of Managua. (points up the statue's  ass) What are we doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Claire addresses Alex calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rafael is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Alex isn't quite sure he understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the picture he's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupts quickly) Who cares how?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. A bit of gallows laughter from Alex as he circle the statue. Price calms and tries to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alex... I think I finally saw one  too many bodies. (beat) Somoza is a killer. (beat) I thought the war would end sooner. (beat) How many reasons do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
